DataElement.preferredDefinition: the anatomic location of the spread of the cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: the progression of a patient's brain tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: That part of the central nervous system contained within the cranium, comprising the prosencephalon, mesencephalon, and rhombencephalon. It is derived from the anterior part of the embryonic neural tube. Functions include muscle control and coordination, sensory reception and integration, speech production, memory storage, and the elaboration of thought and emotions.

Concepts.definition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

Property.preferredDefinition: Progression; advancement in extent or severity.

Concepts.definition: Progression; advancement in extent or severity.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the anatomic site of brain tumor progression.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of, or related to, or in the direction of the front of the body.

Concepts.definition: Of, or related to, or in the direction of the front of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The uppermost portion of the brainstem located between the pons and the diencephalon. The midbrain contains the cerebral peduncles, oculomotor, trochlear and red nuclei, substantia nigra and various other nuclei and tracts.

Concepts.definition: The uppermost portion of the brainstem located between the pons and the diencephalon. The midbrain contains the cerebral peduncles, oculomotor, trochlear and red nuclei, substantia nigra and various other nuclei and tracts.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The rostral extensions of the ventricular system of the brain consisting of two cavities, one on each side of the brain within the central regions of each cerebral hemisphere.  Cerebrospinal fluid flows from the lateral ventricles into the centrally third ventricle via the foramen of Monroe.

Concepts.definition: The rostral extensions of the ventricular system of the brain consisting of two cavities, one on each side of the brain within the central regions of each cerebral hemisphere.  Cerebrospinal fluid flows from the lateral ventricles into the centrally third ventricle via the foramen of Monroe.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Aqueduct of sylvius

Concepts.definition: A channel that connects the third and fourth ventricles of the brain.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lower lateral part of the cerebral hemisphere.

Concepts.definition: One of the cerebral lobes. It is located inferior to the frontal and parietal lobes and anterior to the occipital lobe.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The middle portion of the brainstem located between the midbrain and the medulla oblongata. The fourth ventricle lies dorsal to the pons which also contains the motor trigeminal nuclei and the abducens nuclei. The cerebellum contributes a large number of afferent fibers to the pons.

Concepts.definition: The middle portion of the brainstem located between the midbrain and the medulla oblongata. The fourth ventricle lies dorsal to the pons which also contains the motor trigeminal nuclei and the abducens nuclei. The cerebellum contributes a large number of afferent fibers to the pons.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A centrally placed component of the ventricular system of the brain located in the diencephalon. Cerebrospinal fluid from the lateral ventricles flows into the third ventricle via the foramina of Monroe and exits the third ventricle via the aqueduct of Sylvius. The thalamus and hypothalamus border the lateral walls of the third ventricle.

Concepts.definition: A centrally placed component of the ventricular system of the brain located in the diencephalon. Cerebrospinal fluid from the lateral ventricles flows into the third ventricle via the foramina of Monroe and exits the third ventricle via the aqueduct of Sylvius. The thalamus and hypothalamus border the lateral walls of the third ventricle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The two innermost layers of tissue that cover the brain and spinal cord, the arachnoid mater and the pia mater.

Concepts.definition: The two innermost layers of tissue that cover the brain and spinal cord, the arachnoid mater and the pia mater.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of, or relating to, or associated with the parietal bones.

Concepts.definition: Of, or relating to, or associated with the parietal bones.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The lower portion of the brainstem located between the pons and brainstem. This structure contains several descending and ascending tracts, lower cranial nerve nuclei, a significant proportion of the reticular system of the brainstem and other structures.

Concepts.definition: The lower portion of the brainstem located between the pons and brainstem. This structure contains several descending and ascending tracts, lower cranial nerve nuclei, a significant proportion of the reticular system of the brainstem and other structures.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fourth ventricle

Concepts.definition: A diamond-shaped cavity filled with cerebrospinal fluid within the pons extending between the obex in the caudal medulla and the aqueduct of Sylvius in the cerebellum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to a neck, or cervix, in any sense.

Concepts.definition: Relating to a neck, or cervix, in any sense.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of, or related to, or in the direction of the occiput, or back of the head.

Concepts.definition: Of, or related to, or in the direction of the occiput, or back of the head.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Dorsal exophytic brainstem
Cisterna magna

Concepts.definition: The largest of the three principle cisterns in the subarachnoid space which is located between the cerebellum and the medulla oblongata.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Thoracic

Concepts.definition: Having to do with the chest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The portion of the brain located at the base of the skull that is responsible for balance, equilibrium and movement.

Concepts.definition: The portion of the brain located at the base of the skull that is responsible for balance, equilibrium and movement.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Spinal cord (C1 and below)
subcortical masses of gray matter of the cerebrum, namely, the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, amygdala, and clastrum; involved in initiating and directing voluntary movements.

Concepts.definition: Clusters of neurons comprising the globus pallidus, putamen, caudate, nucleus accumbens, substantia nigra and subthalamic nucleus. They are involved with high level aspects of inhibitory motor activity in coordination with the excitation commands issued from the cerebellum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The area of the body below the ribs and above the hipbones.

Concepts.definition: The region of the spine below the ribs and above the hipbones.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cerebellar peduncle

Concepts.definition: Definition not available.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A white matter structure within the cleft that separates the left and right cerebral hemispheres in the mammalian brain. It is composed of a wide, flat bundle of 200-250 million axonal projections.

Concepts.definition: A white matter structure within the cleft that separates the left and right cerebral hemispheres in the mammalian brain. It is composed of a wide, flat bundle of 200-250 million axonal projections.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (THAL-a-muss) An area of the brain that helps process information from the senses and transmit it to other parts of the brain.

Concepts.definition: An ovoid mass composed predominantly of gray substance and associated laminae of white substance. The thalamus is divided into anterior, medial, and lateral parts. The function of the thalamus is to relay sensory impulses and cerebellar and basal ganglia projections to the cerebral cortex. The thalamus is positioned within the posterior part of the diencephalon forming most of each lateral wall of the third ventricle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Conus

Concepts.definition: Definition not available.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cerebellar hemisphere

Concepts.definition: Definition not available.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Optic chiasm

Concepts.definition: hypothalamic structure formed by the crossing of optic nerve fibers from the medial half of each retina.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The second cranial nerve.

Concepts.definition: The second cranial nerve.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cauda equina

Concepts.definition: The collection of spinal nerve roots, arising from lumbar pairs two through five, sacral pairs one through five, and the coccygeal nerve, that branch off the conus medularis at the termination of the spinal cord, and float freely within the lumbar cistern before exiting the spinal column at the appropriate vertebra.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cerebellar vermis

An important supervisory center in the brain, rich in ganglia, nerve fibers, and synaptic connections. It is composed of several sections called nuclei, each of which controls a specific function. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature, blood pressure, heartbeat, metabolism of fats and carbohydrates, and sugar levels in the blood. Through direct attachment to the pituitary gland, the hypothalamus also meters secretions controlling water balance and milk production in the female. The role of the hypothalamus in awareness of pleasure and pain is well established in the laboratory. It is involved in the expression of emotions, such as fear and rage, and in sexual behaviors. Despite its numerous vital functions, the hypothalamus in humans accounts for only 1/300 of total brain weight, and is about the size of an almond. Structurally, it is joined to the thalamus; the two work together to monitor the sleep-wake cycle.

Concepts.definition: An important supervisory center in the brain, rich in ganglia, nerve fibers, and synaptic connections. It is composed of several sections called nuclei, each of which controls a specific function. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature, blood pressure, heartbeat, metabolism of fats and carbohydrates, and sugar levels in the blood. Through direct attachment to the pituitary gland, the hypothalamus also meters secretions controlling water balance and milk production in the female. The role of the hypothalamus in awareness of pleasure and pain is well established in the laboratory. It is involved in the expression of emotions, such as fear and rage, and in sexual behaviors. Despite its numerous vital functions, the hypothalamus in humans accounts for only 1/300 of total brain weight, and is about the size of an almond. Structurally, it is joined to the thalamus; the two work together to monitor the sleep-wake cycle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A small endocrine gland in the brain, situated beneath the back part of the corpus callosum, that secretes melatonin.

Concepts.definition: A small endocrine gland in the brain, situated beneath the back part of the corpus callosum, that secretes melatonin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Three sections, the midbrain, pons and medulla oblongata, that are located at the base of the brain. The brain stem regulates the central nervous system, and is vital as a conduit for motor and sensory innervations.

Concepts.definition: Three sections, the midbrain, pons and medulla oblongata, that are located at the base of the brain. The brain stem regulates the central nervous system, and is vital as a conduit for motor and sensory innervations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cavernous sinus

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of dural venous sinuses located on either side of the pituitary fossa and lateral to the sella turcica. It receives blood from the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins, and drains via the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses, as well as into the emissary vein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Be specific about something; define clearly.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: Named locations of or within the body.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Reassignment of Representation term concept from C37901 (site) to C13717 (anatomic site) as part of structured caDSR harmonization activity 10/10/2006.
